Blood Death Knight.note: Find a way to track  "The 50 Verses of Radiance" and  "The 50 Verses of Resilience" conveniently. You ideally want to have a reminder when  "The 50 Verses of Radiance" reaches more than 45 stacks (to be aware that you will need to read the book soon) and when  "The 50 Verses of Resilience" is up while  Tome of Light's Devotion is off cooldown. You should not macro this into any other ability, as you will need to carefully manage its on-use effect. For 20 seconds after using  Tome of Light's Devotion, its effect is doubled.The entire purpose of this trinket is maximizing  "The 50 Verses of Radiance" uptime;  "The 50 Verses of Resilience" is terrible.Both stances come with a hidden Secondary stat buff -  "The 50 Verses of Radiance" provides Critical Strike, while  "The 50 Verses of Resilience" provides Armor.In raid, you should endeavor to start a fight in  "The 50 Verses of Resilience" with  Tome of Light's Devotion off cooldown so you can instantly switch to the buffed  "The 50 Verses of Radiance" phased on pull.
This trinket cuts above the rest on long fights or in Mythic+. Do not get baited by the tooltip - the stack decay is one stack every 2 seconds out of combat, or 20 seconds to fully drop all stacks.
This provides passive damage and passive trickle healing. It loses steam the moment you add a second target, but not enough to be considered worthless.
Passive damage with a couple of additional gimmicks. Not great, not bad, just competitively tuned enough to warrant a mention.
This trinket's value will massively depend on your Critical Strike rate and uptime on targets while the effect is up.
It can hit the same target multiple times as the projectile goes through them.
Trinkets with an on-use stat effect are not our favorite kind, and this is no exception. As Deathbringer, use it with Mark; as San'layn, hold it for  Dancing Rune Weapon.
Does damage. Doesn't do much of it, but does enough to justify being a middle-of-the-pack trinket. That's about it, really.
Gives you a random amount of stats on a somewhat frequent proc interval; you can expect around 50% uptime split randomly between the two buffs.
The gimmick on this one is that this spawns guardians that are buffed by our spec aura's effect. We effectively get more value out of this as we get buffed via hotfixes!
B-tier if you're the only one using it, A-tier if you and three DPS in the party use it with all of them proccing a different Secondary (because of the gain of other people, not yours).

Ignore what the tooltip says, because it is literally counterproductive.When you use it, Pitbot Geardo spawns on the side of your target and douses everything within 4 yards in  Oily Outrage every 0.5 seconds. After 5 seconds, it detonates, and the threat from the damage it deals is attributed to you.

Shadow-Binding Ritual Knife is literally better everywhere, does not cost a Spark or Crests to craft, and is better defensively to boot. There is no logical reason to craft  Algari Alchemist Stone unless you drastically overvalue its meager, uncontrollable, infrequent proc, or erroneously assume its Secondary static budget is somehow better than the rest.
The buff it provides has no visible remaining duration, but appears to be capable of fading out of combat.

Losing two to three GCDs for this little damage should just be illegal. The only saving grace of this trinket is that it itself is not on the GCD, allowing you to... not really do much with it. But you could if you were playing  Blooddrinker!

Shadow-Binding Ritual Knife is literally better everywhere, does not cost a Spark or Crests to craft, and is better defensively to boot. There is no logical reason to craft  Algari Alchemist Stone unless you drastically overvalue its meager, uncontrollable, infrequent proc, or erroneously assume its Secondary static budget is somehow better than the rest.

Frost Death Knight.note: If you have a Myth track version of this trinket from Season 1, you will want to hold onto it until you get a Hero track  House of Cards or Delve trinket. This trinket performs incredibly well against the Season 2 pool, as very few in Season 2 provide a strong buff on a 90-second cooldown.

This trinket is a potent stat stick, granting Mastery and Strength. The damage dealt while fully empowered is unremarkable and seems mostly for flavor. Despite the downside of losing stacks between packs, this trinket is still a strong option in Mythic+ and will do well for key groups that keep pulling, even if it drops once or twice on a longer run between packs.

Frost loves Critical Strike, so it is no surprise to see a trinket with a Critical Strike proc near the top of the list. Frost has plenty of passive damage sources that can critically hit to get the maximum duration. This trinket falls short of S tier due to poor timing on the proc making it difficult to line up with  Pillar of Frost.

Although it is limited to Hero track at best, this trinket is a great pickup in the early season. Frost should always have Versatility as its lowest stat, so the low stat proc still provides a nice flat damage buff.
This is another Delve trinket worth getting early on. The Mastery proc gets high uptime, somewhere around 50%, providing persistent buffs to most of Frost's abilities.

Although  Breath of Sindragosa should prefer a 2-minute on-use over other options, the magnitude of the Secondary buff is underwhelming compared to  House of Cards. However, it still provides a hefty amount of Strength so it will be worth wearing until obtaining a Hero track delve or Raid trinket.

If you have a Myth track version of this trinket from Season 1, you will want to hold onto it until you get a Hero track  House of Cards or Delve trinket. This trinket performs incredibly well against the Season 2 pool, as very few in Season 2 provide a strong buff on a 90-second cooldown.

Unfortunately, this trinket misses the tuning mark. It is an okay trinket for  Breath of Sindragosa builds at best. The Strength buff loses some of its power budget to the single-target damage effect, so it is not as effective as it could be in  Breath of Sindragosa's strongest environments.

Sadly, one of the more unique trinkets this season is noticeably lackluster for us. It offers nothing we can interact with, and the damage of the summons is simply too low for us to want this outside of as a placeholder if you get lucky with Raid loot the first couple of weeks.
Although the Strength on this trinket looks attractive, the average uptime on the Strength is too low and the direct damage is too weak for it to be worth considering.

Unholy Death Knight.note: Alongside  Suspicious Energy Drink, this is also a potent trinket. It is best in slot, given you can obtain it at 665 item level from your Vault. For encounters that last longer than 5 minutes,  Eye of Kezan can win out, but would require a 6+ minute encounter to do so, and never in Mythic+.
Another potent passive stat proc trinket. This is the best option for us in high downtime scenarios, and even in raid before obtaining  Eye of Kezan.

One of the only other 1.5-minute on-use stat trinkets available to us in Season 2 of The War Within. The only thing preventing this from being the best is its maximum item level holding it back. Until you get  House of Cards, this is our best-on-use trinket.
Another potent passive stat proc trinket. This is the best option for us in high downtime scenarios, and even in raid before obtaining  Eye of Kezan.
A rather potent proc trinket, given that it is Critical Strike-based. While it won't be the best passive stat trinket you can get your hands on, it will still provide a respectable damage increase.
Another passive pet proc trinket. Slightly weaker than  Zee's Thug Hotline, but still respectable.
A good passive stat proc trinket.
Another good pure damage trinket that only lags behind by not providing stats.
Another passive pet proc trinket. Slightly weaker than  Zee's Thug Hotline, but still respectable.
Being an on-use damage trinket, this suffers heavily compared to alternatives. It provides some decent movement utility in a pinch, but that's not quite enough to make this trinket good.
Being an on-use damage trinket, this just can't compete with stat-based trinkets.
A hybrid stat and damage on-use trinket, its value being split between these two competing values, along with its 2-minute cooldown, result in it just being mediocre.

Vengeance Demon Hunter.note: This trinket provides a static Mastery gain. It has a 5 RPPM proc that grants stacking Main stat (in our case, Agility) up to 20 times worth about 1.8x a normal trinket. When fully stacked, it deals damage on proc instead. It takes 4 minutes to fully stack up. When out of combat, it has a 20 second duration and additionally loses 1 stack every 2 seconds, so dropping it is extremely punishing. If you are at full stacks, you will drop from 20 to 11 stacks over the course of the 20 seconds and then lose all remaining stacks when the buff runs out. This makes it excellent for raiding, but not so great for Mythic+ with combat downtime. However, if you chain-pull and use a couple creative toys to stay in combat, this can still be powerful.

The on-use effect grants a good amount of your highest Secondary stat for 20 seconds on a 2 minute cooldown. Additionally, has a minor benefit for any allies also using the trinket. Syncs up well with  Metamorphosis for large burst.

This trinket provides a static Haste gain. It has a 1.5 minute cooldown and generates a 75% damage absorption shield worth roughly half of maximum Health, so it still allows some damage through for our self-healing kit to continue working. It also deals a small amount of damage when it ends. The lack of a main stat makes this slightly worse than usual, but a strong defensive option.

1.5 + Haste RPPM proc that summons an AoE cart, similar to  Geargrinder's Spare Keys, but on a proc instead of on-use. It also deals Physical damage instead, making it less valuable. Requires a Havoc loot spec to obtain.
3 RPPM proc that grants either your highest or lowest Secondary stat for 10 sec. The lowest Secondary gains ~33% more stat than your highest.
Radiance mode: Grants some Critical Strike and your attacks have a chance to deal bonus Holy damage.
This trinket provides a static Mastery gain. 1 RPPM proc that grants a large amount of Agility for 15 seconds (roughly 4 times a standard trinket).

1.5 minute cooldown on-use effect that deals a large amount of Shadow damage to your target and a much smaller amount of uncapped AoE damage to all enemies behind it. The cone is quite small, so it can be hard to hit everything. Is not currently affected by the Tank penalty, despite requiring Havoc loot spec to obtain.

2 RPPM on a 15 second large Primary stat buff and minor shield for allies, with roughly half the stat gained for ourselves and a shield worth about 1/15 of max Health. Dropping below 50% Health also grants an extra proc, so it's really more like 3 procs per minute. The stat buff is fairly valuable for the group, but the trinket itself isn't particularly good for us if working as intended. However, it's currently bugged to absorb far more than intended, and can even work like a cheat death for both you as well as whichever ally it procs on, so it's quite powerful defensively.

5 RPPM proc that grants a stacking minor Haste buff up to 5 times. When it reaches maximum stacks, it doubles the Haste for 15 seconds and then resets. Takes roughly 1 minute to fully stack, so on average it is worth roughly 4.4 stacks on a 75 second interval.

Grants a 15 second Critical Strike buff on the first ability used every minute, extending by 1 second from any critical hits up to a maximum of 30 seconds. This should almost always have maximum uptime, given that we tend to have a good amount of Critical Strike.

This trinket provides a static Haste gain. It has a high chance to proc bonus single-target Physical or AoE Fire damage, depending on which mode it's set to. The Physical damage is roughly 15% more than Fire after armor is taken into account, so they are roughly equal at 5 targets. It appears to have a 3 second ICD and around 5 RPPM. Requires a Havoc loot spec to obtain.
2.5 RPPM proc that summons one of 5 pets to deal bonus damage for 10 seconds.  Bloodlust effects summon all 5 at once. Requires a Havoc loot spec to obtain.

1.5 minute cooldown that grants a large amount of Mastery per use and stacks the deck until you leave combat, which increases the minimum gained by roughly 3% per stack. Unfortunately, this doesn't line up with any of our cooldowns and the maximum bonus isn't reached until 4.5 minutes, making it not that great even in raid despite the large boost. The bonus effect will never stack in Mythic+. If you use this trinket, it's actually better to sync it with  Metamorphosis and treat it like a 2 minute trinket, but that reduces its value significantly.

10+Haste RPPM proc to add stacks up to 30 stacks. 20 sec cooldown for the on-use effect, which detonates the stacks for a large amount of Plague damage, plus an additional 10% of that damage over 6 seconds to 5 nearby enemies (linearly scaling with targets, so it can deal up to 50% bonus damage in AoE). It has good flexibility due to the short cooldown and high stack generation, but can take up to 3 minutes (divided by Haste) to fully stack. Requires a Havoc loot spec to obtain.

1.5 + Haste RPPM proc that summons an AoE cart, similar to  Geargrinder's Spare Keys, but on a proc instead of on-use. It also deals Physical damage instead, making it less valuable. Requires a Havoc loot spec to obtain.

This trinket provides a static Versatility gain. Its 2 minute cooldown on-use effect grants a 100% damage absorption shield for roughly half Health and deals a small amount of damage to enemies. The cooldown is reduced by the presence of any DoTs on you by 22 seconds, but this does not work with self-DoTs such as  Set Fire to the Pain. This trinket could be useful against some debuffs, but baseline it is not too strong.

Grants a small 50% absorption shield worth roughly 1/10 of max Health whenever you drop below 60% with a 30 sec ICD. If it doesn't proc for 20 seconds, it grants a small amount of Haste. This is not a particularly great trinket, since it's likely to proc nearly on cooldown whenever we don't have a strong defensive up. Additionally, it procs after we've already lost Health, so it's particularly weak against Tankbusters, though it's decent against small amounts of sustained damage.

An on-use effect with a 1.5 minute cooldown, which grants some bonus threat on all nearby enemies and then deals damage. Enemies that were initially debuffed take extra damage. A creative idea, but not particularly strong.

An on-use effect with a 1.5 minute cooldown that moves you to the nearby ground-targeted location, dealing split AoE damage. It has a short cast time (1 second divided by Haste). It's not very good and is rather clunky to use.

0.5+Haste RPPM proc that can summon a helper which deals some damage or heals you while granting a large stat buff to any nearby ally. Unfortunately, the proc rate is so low that it's hard to make good use of it.
An on-use effect with a 2 minute cooldown that deals Physical damage split in AoE in a ground-targeted area after 10 seconds. This is annoying to use, especially if you ever need to move.
5+Haste RPPM proc that deals Holy Fire damage and heals you for half that amount when you take damage.
An on-use effect with a 1.5 minute cooldown that grants either Haste or Critical Strike randomly.
3 RPPM proc on melee that deals a small amount of damage. Grants a 20% speed boost for 10 seconds if you score well.
4+Haste RPPM proc that puts a 5 second Nature DoT on target. Grants 25% speed if the target dies while debuffed.
This trinket provides a static Critical Strike gain. It has an on-use effect with a 3 minute cooldown that summons a pirate to assist for 20 seconds.

The passive effect of this trinket applies a stacking debuff on your target (up to 5 stacks) from all spells and abilities. It has an on-use effect with a 1.5 minute cooldown that deals damage instantly, plus ~11% bonus per stack as a DoT.
3RPPM to gain a Mastery proc for 10 seconds whenever you use offensive abilities. This proc receives a ~16% bonus if you are under 35% Health when it procs.

No static stat. 2 RPPM proc that increases Agility by a decent amount, up to 5 stacks. When it reaches 5 stacks, it deals a small amount of AoE split damage and maintains the stacks for 15 seconds before resetting. It takes roughly 2.5 minutes to fully stack up, so it's on a 135 second cycle with 2.78 average stacks over time. This means that it grants roughly 25% more stat than a standard trinket of equivalent item level without any other effect. However, the buff can drop out of combat and is half of what the tooltip states.

An on-use effect with a 1.5 minute cooldown that moves you slightly forward and deals damage split amongst all enemies that are hit. This is extremely bad for Tanks as it forces repositioning and can cause you get hit in the back, negating your avoidance. It doesn't even do enough damage to justify its use. Requires a Havoc loot spec to obtain.
An on-use effect with a 1 minute cooldown that fires 1-3 grenades dealing split Fire damage to enemies.
2+Haste RPPM on taking damage effect that grants a small damage absorption shield and deals damage when broken.

An on-use effect with a 2 minute cooldown that channels for 2 seconds, dealing damage at 1 second intervals. The damage is actually per tick, and it has a niche effect where it will allow you to deal bonus damage to any Mechanical enemies affected by it. However, it is a channeled ability, so it can be rather dangerous for a Tank to use and you are losing actual globals to channel it.
Grants a stacking buff for every enemy killed up to 20. It has an on-use effect with a 1.5 minute cooldown that heals for about 10% of maximum Health, plus a bonus .5% HoT effect per stack.

An on-use effect with a 2 minute cooldown that grants 4 stacks of armor for 30 seconds, with each stack being removed when taking more than 10% of your maximum Health from Physical damage in a hit. This was one of, if not the worst, trinkets in the game when it was introduced, and is still awful.

Feral Druid.note: An alternate on use trinket that lines up with CDs, it SHOULD also be giving you mastery.

Restoration Druid.note: A strong flat healing trinket that particularly excels in raid.

An incredible, overbudget, trinket but one that's particularly strong in the second half of a fight. Some caution needs to be taken if a fight is front loaded. The healing proc portion is for flavor and most of the power is in the massive intellect buff.
One of the more powerful on-use trinkets for us this tier since we're able to line it up with every second Flourish and it'll give us Haste.
A capable stat stick with decent uptime.
An overpowered Delve trinket that caps out on the Hero track. Very good if you're able to get one early.
Lower on average stat gain than we'd like but Haste is a good stat and the uptime is good.
Quite good on paper but we really don't have anything on a 90 second cooldown to combine it with.
High variance and not all that strong.
Useful in some specific keys where giving someone extra health is valuable.
We can stack the trinket very fast but crit is not a good stat for us.
Ruby can be combined with every second Flourish cast but crit is such an awful stat that you'd really rather wear something else.
Only usable in Mythic+ where you're able to avoid dropping low on mana since it's really the versatility portion that's valuable. A little strange for a Mana Battery.
A poor trinket that you'll replace quickly.
You'd like this to do more healing given it's missing intellect.

Devastation Evoker.note: Passive trinket that rapidly stacks Critical Strike when it procs.
On-use trinket that grants a random amount of Mastery. The bottom of the range increases in value with each use. Best in slot for Raid and Mythic+.
Passive trinket that stacks over time then deals damage at max stacks. If you die, you lose your stacks.
On-use trinket that also buffs nearby allies who are also using it. Use with cooldowns.
Spawns a candle near you. Gain Versatility while standing near it, increasing over time.
Random chance to increase your Mastery. More effective when low on health.
Passive Haste proc that stacks. At full stacks you gain twice as much Haste for a short time, then the buff resets.

This trinket summons candle pets that attack your target. It does a surprising amount of damage.  The AI on the minions it spawns is kind of bad, and requires you to stay near your target. Only really recommended for Single Target.
On-use trinket that gives Critical Strike, increasing in value if the target is low health. Use with cooldowns.
On-use trinket that shoot a motorcycle at the enemy. Damage on the resulting explosion is unfortunately split.
Randomly spawn a barrel that will explode when killed. This would be higher tier, but our spells don't seem to like to hit it.
On-use trinket that either gives Critical Strike or Haste. Use with cooldowns.
Orbs spawn that give you a damage bonus when you pick them up.
Passive damage proc trinket that shocks your target every 6 seconds and chains to another enemy. Casting 30 spells turbo-charges the rate it hits and the damage.
This trinket has two modes. Using the trinket will swap between  Precision Blasting (Single Target) and  Mass Destruction (AoE - Split damage).
On-use trinket that gives intellect. After casting 3 spells, fire a beam that hits your target and up to 5 enemies on the way. Best paired with cooldowns.
Build up to 5 poison stacks. Use the trinket to consume these stacks and deal heavy damage.

Season 1 trinket. Flexible on-use trinket that functions as a stat stick and a powerful steroid. Generally, we stack this buff until 31+ and use with cooldowns. Make sure you use the last of your stacks before combat ends. Dying removes your stacks, so beware!

Preservation Evoker.note: A surprisingly overpowered healing trinket. A locked in choice until you're doing very high end content.
Very powerful over a fight, though it's very back-loaded so I'd advise swapping it out on fights where most of the healing is in the first phase or portion of the fight.
As Preservation we'll line this up with every Stasis cast to further bolster our already huge burst healing.
We don't have any great cooldowns to line up with Ruby but the high average stat value keeps it very competitive.
We're not the fastest stacker of this trinket but we love crit and it's a reliable choice.
Similar to Ruby, we don't do a ton of healing on a two minute cadence but it still averages quite a lot of stats.
A generic but well tuned stat stick. You don't have to worry too much about the 'stand in the light' portion.
A very overpowered Delve trinket that could top the list except it's only available on the Hero track. One of the best at its item level.
A fairly disappointing back up option if you can't get any of the above trinkets. Very high variance.
Not very good on overall throughput but might find niche uses in Mythic+ where giving someone on your team effective health can be very valuable - especially on higher key levels.
Haste isn't too bad for us now but this trinket is a little low on average stat gain.
The versatility portion is quite strong but the trinket falls apart if you ever lose it which is quite easy to do.
A generic healing trinket that you'll replace quickly.
Undertuned for a trinket that doesn't have intellect on it.

Augmentation Evoker.note: This is a strong passive option for Augmentation Evoker with a straightforward effect that is expected to provide consistent value. It's powerful in all content and with no major caveats this is one of the best trinkets available this season.

This is a strong passive trinket with ideal stats for Augmentation Evoker, however it loses value quickly in short, bursty encounters. This means that this will be a strong option for progression-style raid encounters, but unlikely to be nearly as effective in short fights or Mythic+.

As currently implemented, this is one of the more interesting new trinkets available. This trinket will randomly spawn barrels in range of enemy targets that cannot be hit by AoE or cleave effects and must be deliberately attacked, not unlike the old M+ affix  Explosive. The damage potential of this trinket is quite potent, presumably to compensate for the opportunity cost of spending a global to destroy the barrel, and also given that some barrel explosions might miss the mark if you are not careful or are particularly unlucky.Augmentation Evoker is one of few specs in the game that is able to spend a cast to hit the barrel without incurring a substantial opportunity cost (particularly in Single Target), which is done by casting  Living Flame with  Pupil of Alexstrasza talented. It is also technically possible to interact with barrels spawned by allies, provided that the barrel spawns are allowed to overlap and at least one barrel is allowed to remain up. If you do use this trinket, consider a Weakaura to highlight the barrels and their remaining active time, and perhaps also a macro to target and cast  Living Flame.

This has potential as an on-use trinket, particularly in group play if you are able to align your cooldown usage with teammates for extra value. As mentioned above, this can be a challenge depending on your group and talent setup, and will have limited synergy with  Best-in-Slots.

This is a classic on-use stat trinket with potential to provide extra value if you are able to snipe low-health enemies, but it comes with the same caveats as other 2-min on-use trinkets as mentioned.

This does have reasonable potential as an on-use source of Mastery if you are able to align this with your  Breath of Eons burst windows, but on-use Mastery is somewhat situational for Augmentation, and loses significant value if you are not able to align it with your major group buffs.
This is a very straightforward and solid passive option for Augmentation Evoker with an effect that persists out-of-combat or in between pulls, making this a solid pick for Mythic+ content.

This is actually a rather interesting trinket with the ability to swap its damage profile between single target and AoE. While it doesn't provide Intellect, Haste is still a reasonable stat for Augmentation, and direct damage effects also often provide outsized value for Augmentation.
This trinket has unique potential as an actual source of on-use Intellect, but it is still an on-use trinket and carries the aforementioned caveats.

Perhaps the most popular caster trinket from Season 1, this trinket is still likely to be a reasonable option at Season 1 Myth track item level given its immense potential for burst once you've accumulated stacks. Just note that this may see further tuning as Season 2 progresses.

This is a high-value passive trinket that makes a return in Season 2 as part of the Delve drop table. Just note that as a Delve trinket, it may eventually be outmatched by higher item level options from Raid and Mythic+.

As another somewhat popular Delve trinket from Season 1, this trinket deals reasonable damage in Single Target encounters, but loses value as additional targets are added. Additionally the same caveats apply when it comes to Delve trinkets and item level.

This newly-added Delve trinket is actually somewhat similar to  Geargrinder's Spare Keys, however the 10-second charge-up time certainly leaves something to be desired. The same caveats apply when it comes to Delve trinkets and item level.

This newly-added Delve trinket is actually somewhat similar to  Geargrinder's Spare Keys, however the 10-second charge-up time certainly leaves something to be desired. The same caveats apply when it comes to Delve trinkets and item level.

Beast Mastery Hunter.note: Not as good as  Signet of the Priory, but definitely still solid.
Decent enough crafted option if you really need a trinket.

The strongest of the several on-use AoE abilities. The rest,  Ravenous Honey Buzzer,  Charged Stormrook Plume and  Garbagemancer's Last Resort generally come with some condition that limits their usefulness.

The strongest of the several on-use AoE abilities. The rest,  Ravenous Honey Buzzer,  Charged Stormrook Plume and  Garbagemancer's Last Resort generally come with some condition that limits their usefulness.
Unrealistic as the AoE has short range and would require you to dance into melee range.

Marksmanship Hunter.note: Near-BiS alternative to Signet, especially for Â Dark Ranger.
A very strong Trinket, but does rely on being synced with  Trueshot to be good. Simulations do this fairly well (as well as they can with a strict 60s timer), but reality can be different.
Our best on-use Trinket. Used on every 2nd  Trueshot.
Supremely powerful for prolonged encounters/Raiding scenarios, but very poor for sub-4-minute encounters. C-Tier in Mythic+.
Near-BiS alternative to Signet, especially for Â Dark Ranger.
Extremely strong for pure single-target and priority-target damage.

Survival Hunter.note: Fairly decent for a delve trinket, but not quite at the level of  Signet of the Priory which is simply farmable from m+. It can still be useful in a pinch until you manage to get a replacement however.

Similar to  Signet of the Priory, this is an extremely powerful on-use trinket. The main benefit of  House of Cards is that it lines up perfectly with Sentinel's Â  Coordinated Assault when paired with  Sentinel Watch, making it very powerful for m+.
Very similar to  Improvised Seaforium Pacemaker, but tuned slightly worse. As a stat trinket it is great for AoE, however it performs very poorly for ST.

This is an extremely strong stat stick with a ramp-up time. Although the ramp-up and out of combat decay makes it unsuitable for Mythic+, it is extremely powerful for raids. If you manage to get your hands on one of these it is prettymuch a lock-in for any fight that lasts longer than 6 minutes.

If you can manage to get this on hero track, it will serve you well until you manage to get a  Signet of the Priory. It is slightly weaker and slightly more awkward, but it is powerful either way. The cast can be used off-GCD.

This is a great stack stick, working well in both ST and AoE alike. Its real limiting factor is its maximum item level (665) As such, it will drop off as the tier progresses, but if you can get your hands on this early in the tier this will help tremendously!
A decent albeit random mastery/agi stat stick. Stats are always good and scale nicely into AoE.
Honestly, an extremely awkward trinket to use, Jumping is sometimes used for ideal movement or repositioning, and locking yourself from doing so freely is annoying. That said, it is quite powerful.

A decent Versa stat stick with an Agi proc. This is crafted by Alchemists but can be used by anyone. Spending a Spark and Crests on this is generally poor value, but the extra powerful healing potions can be nice.
Split damage trinkets have been buffed slightly in Undermined. This isn't an amazing trinket but it will perform okay ish in both ST and AoE.
Split damage trinkets have been buffed slightly in Undermined. This isn't an amazing trinket but it will perform okay ish in both ST and AoE.
Very similar to  Improvised Seaforium Pacemaker, but tuned slightly worse. As a stat trinket it is great for AoE, however it performs very poorly for ST.

Fairly decent for a delve trinket, but not quite at the level of  Signet of the Priory which is simply farmable from m+. It can still be useful in a pinch until you manage to get a replacement however.
This was extremely powerful in Season 1, but is falling behind now. It doesn't scale as well with Ilvl as some other offerings but it can still perform decently as a passive stat stick.
Sigil of Algari Concordance but with goblins! Turns out, several goblins are barely more lethal a single dwarf. It is a funny trinket but quite mid in the grand scheme.

The channel makes it a little weak for what it is, However, some trinkets can start their channels and casts before a GCD has ended, meaning you could save up to 1.5 seconds on the channel. It is currently unclear how this trinket behaves, but if it ignores GCD its value may go up significantly. Either way, it is a poor ST trinket.

Randomly summons earthen dwarves to assist in battle. They attack your targets a bunch before they leave. It is generally only suitable as a Single Target trinket, but its damage isn't anything to write home about.

Arcane Mage.note: This staff shares cooldowns with trinkets and is a strong steroid due to the fact that we can use it every  Arcane Surge window. You should use this before  Arcane Barrageing into  Touch of the Magi. With double on use builds, you'll want to use this on your first miniburn which will allow you to use it on your 2nd  Arcane Surge and in some cases you can hold  Shifting Power until after your 2nd miniburn so that your 2nd use trinket is used on 3rd  Arcane Surge.
Another strong passive trinket, no playing around this, just equip and forget!

This trinket functions as a passive trinket basically, however you need to be aware of barrels that spawn near your enemies and kiill them. It is suggested that you try to do this outside of cooldowns if possible, the barrels last for a while. There is also a great weakaura for this.
Another good use trinket to use with  Arcane Surge.
Another good use trinket to use with  Arcane Surge.

This trinket will likely be very strong when you can stay in combat for extended durations, it is fairly resilient on this point so it should still be strong in Mythic+ as well. It's fully passive so just equip and forget.
Another good use trinket to use with  Arcane Surge.
Solid use option when used after  Arcane Surge.
Another decent passive option.
Another decent passive option.

Use this well before combat, it's a long channel but the buff last indefinitely. Avoid staying low mana so you don't have to refresh, but also be aware that if you need to refresh you can channel for less time to just recoup what you lost. A weakaura really helps with tracking this.
Another decent passive option.
Basically a passive trinket that you have to click to get the benefit from, prioritize using this so long as it won't interfere with you using a steroid trinket with your cooldowns.
This trinket is kind of annoying, there is no way to track when the fragment spawns with a weakaura so you just have to use your eyes.
The ally is really cute.
Another decent passive option.
Another decent passive option.
Proc damage that goes boom, its not as terrible as it was in Shadowlands!
A solid use trinket, just held back by lower being ilevel.
Okay passive trinket.
Basically a passive trinket that you have to click to get the benefit from, prioritize using this so long as it won't interfere with you using a steroid trinket with your cooldowns with stacks.
Aim to use it 9-10s before  Evocation, then activate the buff when you're ready to burst, this will allow you to use it in multiple consecutive  Arcane Surges despite its cooldown.
Mediocre passive trinket.
Use this before  Evocation.

Fire Mage.note: BiS passive trinket that stacks over time then deals damage at max stacks. If you die, you lose your stacks.
Passive trinket that rapidly stacks Critical Strike when it procs. Critical Strike is converted to Mastery during  Combustion.
On-use trinket that grants a random amount of Mastery. The bottom of the range increases in value with each use. Very strong in Mythic+, and pairs well with the other passive S tier trinkets.
Randomly spawn a barrel that will explode when killed.  Mastery: Ignite is effective at breaking these.
Spawns a candle near you. Gain Versatility while standing near it, increasing over time.
Random chance to increase your Mastery. More effective when low on health.
Passive Haste proc that stacks. At full stacks you gain twice as much Haste for a short time, then the buff resets.
Passive damage proc trinket that shocks your target every 6 seconds and chains to another enemy. Casting 30 spells turbo-charges the rate it hits and the damage.

This trinket summons candle pets that attack your target. It does a surprising amount of damage.  The AI on the minions it spawns is kind of bad, and requires you to stay near your target. Only really recommended for Single Target.
On-use trinket that either gives Critical Strike or Haste. Use with  Combustion.
On-use trinket that gives Critical Strike, increasing in value if the target is low health. Use with  Combustion so that it's converted to Mastery.
On-use trinket that shoot a motorcycle at the enemy. Damage on the resulting explosion is unfortunately split.

Even with Season 1 itemlevel and after nerfs, this is still a strong trinket. Flexible on-use trinket that functions as a stat stick and a powerful steroid. Generally, we stack this buff until 31+ and use with cooldowns. Make sure you use the last of your stacks before combat ends. Dying removes your stacks, so beware!
On-use trinket that also buffs nearby allies who are also using it. Use with cooldowns.
Orbs spawn that give you a damage bonus when you pick them up.
This trinket has two modes. Using the trinket will swap between  Precision Blasting (Single Target) and  Mass Destruction (AoE - Split damage).
On-use trinket that gives intellect. After casting 3 spells, fire a beam that hits your target and up to 5 enemies on the way. Best paired with cooldowns.
Build up to 5 poison stacks. Use the trinket to consume these stacks and deal heavy damage.

Frost Mage.note: This is the most powerful trinket in Season 2 as long as you can stay in combat to maintain its stacks.
A fun trinket that lets you fire out a Geargrinder trike at your target.
This is an active trinket that gets stronger as you stay in combat. It provides stats, so it's generally good in all situations.
This is one of the better passive trinkets from the raid.

A powerful, but difficult to use trinket. While fighting, a Backfill Barrel will sometimes spawn near your targets. You need to target this and cast a damage spell on it to destroy it, dealing AoE damage. This is best handled by using a normal rotational  Ice Lance or  Glacial Spike so that it can potentially still hit your target with  Splitting Ice.
This is generally just a strong passive trinket, but you need to stay in the area of light it creates when it procs.
This is a decent passive trinket that provides haste.
This trinket is pretty good against a single target, but performs poorly in AoE situations.

This passive trinket summons an Earthen ally to assist you and is mainly useful against a single target. You do not need to do anything special to use this trinket, it is simply worth a solid amount of damage against a single target.

This active trinket provides a lot of Critical Strike chance and is better against low health enemies. Because it can easily put you over 33.34% Critical Strike chance, it's not that good for Frost Mages.
A strong trinket against a single target. Because the summoned pet can be a melee attacker, this trinket is better if you stay close to your target.
This is a strong passive trinket that works well against any number of targets.
This is a strong passive trinket that works well against any number of targets.
If you need to craft a trinket, this is the strongest one available.
This active trinket currently seems relatively weak compared to the other options from the raid because it does not line up well with  Icy Veins.

Brewmaster Monk.note: A simple option, this trinket features Static Agility and a potent on-use effect with only a 90-second cooldown. Even in single-target it is your strongest option for on-demand damage.
Once every 90 seconds, you may activate the trinket to immediately force it to switch buffs and double the current effects (both the stat and proc) for 20 seconds.

This trinket features no static stats, so its effect needs to be quite strong in order to make up for mere passive Agility buffing all of your abilities. Fortunately, it is acceptably good, and also buffs your allies while also featuring a guaranteed proc when your health drops low. Moreover, due to the unique way in which this trinket's effects are implemented, it can often absorb far more than it theoretically should be able to. However, wearing this trinket does come with a fairly substantial personal damage loss, though its quirks make it nearly unparalleled for defense.

Mistweaver Monk.note: This trinket blows every other option away. The healing it does is substantial, and it avoids the pitfall of other similar trinkets, where overhealing goes to waste. When it overheals a player, the amount of healing that went to waste is instead converted to damage on nearby enemies, and further amplified. There's genuinely not much else to say about it. It's just incredibly good.

In encounters that last long enough for you to obtain the full amount of stacks from this trinket, it's incredibly strong. Being able to gain as much Intellect as it can give, as well as turning further stacks into more healing or damage makes this one of the best trinkets for those sorts of fights. However, this runs into an issue in Mythic+ dungeons, similar to trying to use  Darkmoon Sigil: Ascension , where the stacks decay too frequently outside of combat. In raids, this is your second pick, while you're looking for a different trinket in Mythic+ dungeons.

One of the only noteworthy trinkets from Delves, this trinket is very similar to  Signet of the Priory, in that it will grant us Haste for each Celestial window we have in raids. Unfortunately, it is a trinket from Delves, and they are only able to be found on the Hero upgrade track, limiting how powerful it can become.

This trinket is very similar to  Signet of the Priory, in that it will increase the healing of every Celestial use (or every other one if we're talented into  Gift of the Celestials). In Mythic+ dungeons, it's far more likely we'll get consistently high amounts of Critical Strike rating from enemies, and that directly translates into more healing during  Invoke Chi-Ji, the Red Crane, as well as more damage from our abilities.

This trinket comes with a baseline amount of Intellect, which already makes it good, and the buff ( Moxie Frenzy) grants a good amount of Critical Strike. It's definitely worth tracking, as having an instance of it active while we've invoked our chosen Celestial will help to increase our throughput.

Nothing much to say about this trinket. A baseline amount of Intellect with a Versatility buff every now and then. The main drawback is that Versatility has a lower transfer rate between the rating it has and the percent throughput increase it gives.

A baseline amount of Intellect and a stacking Haste buff sounds like it'd be amazing for Mistweavers, but the biggest issue is that we're going to be meeting the dminishing return threshold for Haste, meaning we begin to acquire less and less of the stat's rating as we keep gaining more and more of it. This season, we're able to make it past the first theshold, and want to focus some of our rating on Critical Strike or Versatility. This trinket is good if you have little Haste, but that problem will go away as you acquire more and more gear.

This grants Versatility and has a random buff for Intellect. While the Intellect is a good amount, having it be tied to a random event makes it inconsistent, because we would rather have that Intellect on demand for healing during difficult moments, not during downtime.

This trinket has a niche use as another absorb shield with a relatively short cooldown, very similar to how  Life Cocoon functions. While it doesn't remove all of the incoming damage from your target, being able to give them a limited 50% reduction is still very valuable.

One of the only noteworthy trinkets from Delves, this trinket is very similar to  Signet of the Priory, in that it will grant us Haste for each Celestial window we have in raids. Unfortunately, it is a trinket from Delves, and they are only able to be found on the Hero upgrade track, limiting how powerful it can become.

Windwalker Monk.note: Huge Agility and a massively, enormously, gigantic Mastery buff that lines up with our cooldowns. A trinket could not get any better for Windwalker.
Yes, you're reading that correctly. This Delve trinket with a max of 665 is our 2nd best on-use Trinket. It gives a lot of stats and is on a 90-second cooldown.
This is the best equip trinket to pair with House of Cards. Although we'd prefer it to give us more Mastery, even if it gives Crit or Vers, they're strong enough to make this trinket very good.

The best of the dungeon trinkets because it gives you a lot of Agility and your highest secondary stat. The only drawback is that its a 2 minute cooldown instead of a 90-second one, but if you're playing Shado-Pan and/or using your cooldowns every 2-minutes, this is stronger.
Critical Strike isn't our best stat, but its a strong one still, and the uptime is good enough to give it some consideration.

Protection Paladin.note: This is the best trinket available right now. It has passive mastery and stacking primary stat. It also does a damage proc when you hit max stacks of the primary stat. You want to use this in all content.
This is a strong stat stick that excels in AOE and Mythic+.
A very good on-use trinket that aligns with cooldowns. It's more than likely to give you Haste or Crit which are very good for damage.
This is a very strong trinket that you want to use for single-target combat, especially in a raid situation.
This is a strong on-use defensive trinket. It gives some passive haste and the on-use is a large absorb shield.

This trinket doesn't have any baseline main stat or secondary stats. It switches between two states: one that increases armor and one that increases crit. The switching mechanic itself can happen in two ways. The first is when you get hit. There is a hidden counter with a 750ms ICD where you gain stacks of whatever state you're in until you hit 50 then the trinket will automatically swap to the other state. The other way to swap states is to use the on-use. That will swap you to the other state instantly.Speaking of the buffs themselves, the crit buff is more valuable than the armor buff. We have a lot of armor as it is and giving another small amount is less valuable than it might appear.The best way to use this trinket is to use the on-use whenever you can and are in the armor buff state to instantly swap to the crit buff state.

This is a damage on-use trinket that might sim very well. The issue is how it automatically repositions your character and what you're tanking. You might get hit in the back or move mobs in a way that makes your DPS party-mates less effective. just be aware of these things if you use it.

This is a passive defensive trinket that procs when you drop to 60% HP. It has primary stat so it always has value but when it procs, you get a small absorb and some haste. Given that our health can be spikey at times, especially in harder content, it will effectively proc on cooldown.
This is an easy-to-get trinket that you can look into if you have some bad luck with dungeon or raid drops.

This is an on-use defensive trinket with an average amount of absorb on a long cooldown. The cooldown reduction effect could be valuable but there aren't a lot of situations where you have periodic damage.
This is a weak trinket that gives a very small amount of armor. You can avoid it.

Retribution Paladin.note: Passive Critical Strike buff that gets automatically extended as you Crit. No special usage required.

Passive stacking Strength trinket. It takes a while to stack to maximum stacks and decays very quickly out of combat, so it's very strong in Raids but not a good option for Mythic+ or other content. No special usage required.
On use Mastery buff. Use after  Execution Sentence before  Wake of Ashes.
Passive Secondary Stat proc. No special usage required.
On use Haste or Critical Strike buff. Use after  Execution Sentence before  Wake of Ashes.
Passive Critical Strike proc. No special usage required.
Passive Mastery proc. No special usage required.
On use Secondary Stat buff. Use after  Execution Sentence before  Wake of Ashes.
Passive Haste proc. No special usage required.
Passively summons NPCs to attack your target. No special usage required.

Passive damage proc trinket. Strong on single target but unimpressive on AoE. It can be used to convert it to an AoE proc instead of a single target one - this can be done when fighting multiple enemies.
On use Secondary Stat buff. Use after  Execution Sentence before  Wake of Ashes, then jump before the buff expires to prevent yourself from being stunned.
Passive Strength and Mastery statstick. No special usage required.
Passively summons NPCs to attack your target. No special usage required.
Passive damage proc. No special usage required.
Passive Strength proc. No special usage required.

Assassination Rogue.note: With  Eye of Kezan taking the first slot,  Signet of the Priory is a good option to use with our cooldowns. While it is less bursty than  House of Cards it also lasts longer, which balances it out.
With  Eye of Kezan taking the first slot,  Signet of the Priory is a good option to use with our cooldowns. While it is less bursty than  House of Cards it also lasts longer, which balances it out.
With  Eye of Kezan taking the first slot,  Signet of the Priory is a good option to use with our cooldowns. While it is less bursty than  House of Cards it also lasts longer, which balances it out.

In our next tier down,  Improvised Seaforium Pacemaker still sticks out as a possible alternative for our on-use trinket slot. Being a passive that naturally lines up with our cooldowns,  Improvised Seaforium Pacemaker is almost great but needs a bit more to be truly special

Mechano-Core Amplifier is one of the new Delve trinkets that shines as a usable alternative. These are very good for their item level, but they can't compete with the best trinkets since Delve trinkets reach a maximum of hero track. We don't have a preference for which way the amplifier rolls with its proc, as all stats are good for Assassination.

Algari Alchemist Stone is a surprise addition for us after a couple waves of trinket tuning. While it's not the strongest anywhere, it still serves as a solid and reliable option which can be crafted at any time for those getting unlucky with drops.

Outlaw Rogue.note: A powerful on use trinket that lunges you forward on use. The distance you charge forward is similar to  Fel Rush.

An incredibly strong trinket that is held down by the fact you can't increase to a higher reward track. It's a perfect trinket to chase down early in the tier, but it will fall off as you get Mythic gear. Make sure to use  Sprint every time it procs. Movement is not required; it just requires high movement speed.
It is an okay trinket that comes with a stat proc, also provides a buff to your group.

Elemental Shaman.note: Another incredibly strong delve trinket. There is a good chance that this is the best trinket to compete against  House of Cards for the on-use spot. Having no penalty for dropping combat or other stack mechanics means that this trinket can also be used without any losses in Mythic+. The 1.5minute cooldown lines up well with  Ascendance and the Haste is very valuable. The reason this trinket doesn't get S rank is because in case it procs the Critical Strike bonus, it loses a lot of its value.

Our best option for a passive stat stick. Sporting passive Mastery is a good start already and the effect gives a high amount of Intellect throughout a fight, capping out at 20 stacks. After reaching the cap, this trinket deals additional flat damage whenever it procs. The big drawback here is that this stat stick starts rapidly dropping its stacks and thus it value outside of combat which makes this trinket actually useless in Mythic+.

While Critical Strike chance is generally pretty bad for us, this trinket impresses purely by numbers. It cannot keep up with both top trinkets for raiding but it puts up a good fight, performs even better in AoE where Crit is just generally better and most importantly: This trinket does not care if you drop combat. This makes  Mug's Moxie Jug the optimal choice for Mythic+.

The best delve trinket is just completely overbudgeted for its itemlevel. Even on heroic track, this trinket easily keeps up with most mythic trinkets and only loses out against max itemlevel bis trinkets. It ticks all boxes by simply offering high amounts of Mastery and that is before we even take the low health effect into account. I am honestly expecting a nerf here but until then, considering the high availability of delve trinkets, I would definitely try to get this trinket as soon as possible.

Another incredibly strong delve trinket. There is a good chance that this is the best trinket to compete against  House of Cards for the on-use spot. Having no penalty for dropping combat or other stack mechanics means that this trinket can also be used without any losses in Mythic+. The 1.5minute cooldown lines up well with  Ascendance and the Haste is very valuable. The reason this trinket doesn't get S rank is because in case it procs the Critical Strike bonus, it loses a lot of its value.

A fun little Haste stick that cycles through various stages of haste buff until maxing out at 5 stacks roughly once per minute, immediately doubling its value for 15 seconds and then starting again from 0. Sadly, it doesn't seem particularly reasonable to be able to line this up with  Ascendance particularly well without losing uses of  Ascendance which caps this trinket at A-tier. A very fun and very strong trinket though.

A very straight-forward passive stat stick with a Versatility proc. Stay close to the candle to get roughly 10% more stats. Versatility is a stat that we are generally lacking pretty badly, so getting some extra from a trinket works out quite well, both offfensively and defensively. The positional requirement is hard to satisfy at times, when mechanics require you to do otherwise, but because it only ends up losing you 10% it should be quite acceptable in most cases.

Enhancement Shaman.note: While this takes 4 minutes to fully stack, it starts to even out with equivalent trinkets around the 2-3 minute mark. Once it goes above that, and especially when it caps out at 20, this outpaces other trinket options. This makes it strong for longer raid encounters, and is the strongest option on offer. In Mythic+ however, with all the forced combat drops in Season 2 it's unlikely you'll be able to maintain it.

While Crit may not be our most desirable stat, this will proc almost guaranteed every minute. This basically makes it an on-use in disguise that lines up with everyÂ  Doom Winds for Â Totemic, and overlaps with  Ascendance and other on-uses for Â Stormbringer.

An on-use option that Â Stormbringer holds for  Ascendance, while Â Totemic uses on cooldown with  Primordial Wave, and every other cast lines up with  Doom Winds. Also gets slightly more reliable over the course of an encounter.

A generic strong on-use option that will likely be granting you Haste or Mastery, either of which is great. This is especially strong for Â Stormbringer to overlap with  Ascendance, but Â Totemic can layer this with  Doom Winds to great effect as well.

Despite being lower item level and from delves, an extremely good option. Either procs our best stat, or the stat we're least likely to have in diminishing returns. Also has extremely high uptime, so a great passive option.

Despite being lower item level and from delves, an extremely good option. Procs a good amount of Mastery - a stat we want - with an extremely high uptime. The bonus Mastery at lower health is more flavour though, and isn't that useful.
Both hero talents are desperate for as much Haste as possible, and this gives us a cycling amount passively with a solid RPPM. Great passive alternative if you don't have the higher ranked options.
Very unreliable proc, but when it triggers can be explosive if it lines up with cooldown windows. Worth considering as a proc option, though less consistent than the higher ranked picks on the list.

Due to our high amount of Haste we can charge the magnet quite effectively dealing direct damage when used, allowing us to store up some extra burst. Not as strong as stat options, but has some interesting uses to burst down priority targets in raids.

Serves as an alternative on-use if you can't get access to the S tier offerings. Is lower item level and from delves, but works well holding for Â StormbringerÂ  Ascendance, and every other cast lines up with Â Totemic'sÂ  Doom Winds.

Protection Warrior.note: This trinket has 2 parts, the default tooltip is only 50% of what it does:Shield Mode:grants armor and magic absorbSword mode:grants crit and huge dmg procafter you cycle through "50 pages" of either mode by taking damage, it swaps over to the other, you can force this change by using the on-useafter using the on-use mode you swapped to is doubled for 20 secondsThe goal is generally to stay in sword mode as long as possible for an extremely powerful offensive trinket!

The best trinket for every Raid fight. Stacks up throughout the fight and once it reaches maximum stacks it gains a damage proc. Due to losing procs outside of combat it can and will prove difficult to maintain most or any stacks in Mythic+.
Very powerful stat stick for both Raid and Mythic+ alike!
An extremely potent trinket for Mythic+ damage output, it lines up with every use of our cooldowns.
A simple yet strong single-target damage trinket.
The small brother of  Chromebustible Bomb Suit, longer cooldown with unreliable cooldown reduction make it a not as favourable trinket to get.

A solid middle-ground trinket between offense and defense. Provides a small absorb shield when you drop below 60% HP, if this doesn't happen for 20 seconds we instead receive a haste buff. Given our frontloaded mitigation we rarely drop below said threshold resulting in a decent stat stick for offense!
While on paper this trinket may look like it does a lot of damage. The forced movement and lack of any stats on it makes it one of the less than ideal trinkets of the season,
This is an easy-to-get trinket that you can look into if you have some bad luck with dungeon or raid drops.
The small brother of  Chromebustible Bomb Suit, longer cooldown with unreliable cooldown reduction make it a not as favourable trinket to get.
This is a weak trinket that gives a very small amount of armor. One of the most questionable items we have seen in world of warcraft.
